analyzed: jātaka  pakiṇṇaka nipāta  sāli kedāra vagga
translated: Jātaka: Birth Stories🔽The Minor Collection🔽The Chapter with Sālika and Dāruvana
The Sālika and Dāruvana Birth Story
“The Sālika rice is ready,
the doves are eating well.
I confess to you, Brahmā,
I can’t bear to take them away.
But there’s a bird there,
the most beautiful of all.
After eating the rice as he likes,
he takes some in his beak and flies away.”
“Set the birdlime traps
so that you can catch that bird.
And after catching him alive,
bring him to me.”
“After eating and drinking,
the birds fly away.
But I’m caught in a trap—
what bad deed have I done?”
“Your belly is certainly full,
dove, your belly is very full.
After eating the rice as you like,
you take some in your beak and fly away.
Do you fill your storehouse?
Dove, do you have a grudge against me?
When asked, good dove, tell me
where you hide the rice.”
“I have no grudge against you,
and I have no storehouse.
I pay off my debts and give to others,
I have arrived at the Koṭasiṃhalese.
I have hidden a treasure there,
know it thus, Kosiya.”
“What kind of debt and gift is it,
and what is the release from debt?
Explain the hiding of a treasure,
then you will be released from the snare.”
“My young ones, Kosiya, have not yet grown wings,
they are my children.
They will support me, their mother,
therefore I give them a debt.
My mother and father are old,
worn out, past their youth,🔽with their beaks I support them,
I release them from the debt I made before.
There are also other birds there,
whose wings have fallen out, who are very weak,
for their merit I give (them food),

original: taṁ nidhiṁ āhu paṇḍitā.🔽Īdisaṁ me iṇadānaṁ,
analyzed: tam nidhim āhu paṇḍitā  īdisam me iṇa dāna
translated: that is a treasure the wise call.🔽This is the kind of debt and gift,
and this is the release from debt,
I explain the hiding of a treasure,
know it thus, Kosiya.”
“Excellent indeed is this bird,
the bird of the highest Dhamma,
In some humans
this Dhamma is not found.
Eat the rice as you wish,
together with all your relatives;
May we see you again,
I delight in seeing you.”
“I have eaten and drunk enough in your house,

original: Ratī ca no kosiya te sakāse;
analyzed: ratī ca naḥ kosiya te sakāse
translated: And I delight in your presence, Kosiya;
Give gifts to those who have laid aside the rod,
And support your aged mother and father.”
“Today I have gained good fortune,
In that I have seen the supreme bird;
Having heard Suvās’s good words,
I will make much merit.”

analyzed: saḥ kosiyaḥ atta manaḥ udaggaḥ  annañca pānañca abhisaṅkharitvā
translated: Then Kosiya, delighted and joyful,🔽Having prepared food and drink,

analyzed: annena pānena pasanna cittaḥ  santappayi samaṇa brāhmaṇe ca ati
translated: With a serene mind, with food and drink,🔽He satisfied the ascetics and brahmins.
The Sālikeda-rajātaka is the first.
